trial_identification.studytitle: Screening for Colorectal Cancer in Recipients of Kidney Transplants
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Screening for Colorectal Cancer with Faecal Occult Blood Testing and Colonoscopy in Kidney Transplant recipients: a prospective cross-sectional study.
trial_identification.secondaryid: Screnning for Colorectal Cancer in Recipients of Kidney Transplants

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Bowel - Back passage (rectum) or large bowel (colon)

interventions.interventions: 1. Faecal occult blood testing (FOBT). Participants will perform FOBT following enrolment. This involves using a patient kit to sample their own stools for the presence of blood, mailing their testing kit in to a central lab once it is completed. Testing will be conducted once but may involve sampling several stools. 2. Colonoscopy. All participants will also undergo colonoscopy following the completion of FOBT, regardless of the result. This will be performed within a target of 3 months post enrolment.
interventions.comparator: General population offered Colorectal cancer screening with faecal occult blood testing (followed up by colonoscopy if positive).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Sensitivity and specificity of faecal occult blood testing for colorectal cancer and colorectal neoplasia, using colonscopy as the "gold standard" procedure.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: One-off screening with both FOBT and colonoscopy, with a completion target of 3 months post enrolment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Rate of Colorectal Cancer and colorectal neoplasia found at screening colonoscopy.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: One-off screening colonoscopy, with a completion target of 3 months post enrolment.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - Kidney transplant recipients in South Australia >=50 years old, more than 6 months post transplant - Willing and able to give informed consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: - Active unstable cardiopulmonary disease - Terminal illness, life threatening malignancy - Bleeding disorders or unable to stop oral anti-coagulants for colonoscopy - Colonoscopy within 12 months prior to enrolment - Failed kidney transplant and return to dialysis prior to enrolment - Symptoms or signs suggestive of colorectal cancer - Previous personal history of colorectal cancer, advanced adenoma or chronic ulcerative colitis - Family history of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) or Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The risk of cancer, including colorectal cancer is increased in recipients of kidney transplants. This study is designed to evaluate the standard population screening tools for colorectal cancer, ie faecal occult blood testing and colonoscopy, in this high risk population. All recruited patients will undergo both of these screening tests, and from this we will investigate the rates of colorectal cancer and pre-cancerous growths in this population, and the usefulness of the two screening tests for this group of patients.
